column4: I've Googled about GVFS, but haven't found much useful info.  In one sentence, can someone sum up why I, a normal desktop end-user, would want GVFS on my system?  as far as I can tell it only exists to frustrate commands that fail to read it
case in point: the .gvfs file in my home directory: wtf is it and why should i want it?
you would use gvfs if you kept a mirror of a remote drive locally, .gvfs would be the place where it sat
nitinab, is it some kind of network file system protocol?
long story short, you cant get rid of it, nautilus depends on it,
nitinab: I suppose that's useful.  But why is it integral to GNOME?  Seems really weird to be integrated into the GUI layer...
if you can pull nautilus from gnome you wont have gvfs anymore, you wont have nautilus either
can you use this GVFS stuff without using nautilus...? e.g. if i were to log into my machine remotely via ssh and didn't start up a windows session
it's just puzzled me and i haven't been able to understand it from preliminary googling.  where can i find more info on the topic?
I don't undersatnd why something like GVFS would be wanted if we already have NFS
you are looking at gvfs with out a 'use' for it, you got a networked house? more than one pc ?
sorry, important phone call came in.  I'm on a one PC home system, so I have no need to network stuff right now.
I think that's probably teh issue - i don't have the problems it's trying to fix, but i'm still curious
have a network outside the home you want to connect to?
probably the best solution for now.  i'll revisit it later if i need to.  thanks!
